awd_abstract_narration:
With the advent of revolutionary technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI), cloud computing, big data, and Internet of Things (IoT), secure knowledge management (SKM) continues to be an important research area that deals with methodologies for systematically gathering, organizing, and disseminating information in a secure and privacy-preserving manner. The recent development of AI in the security field shows a promising future, and there is no doubt that AI can provide new ideas and tools for secure knowledge management. In order to prepare the next generation, high caliber researchers in SKM areas, it is important to expose graduate students in state-of-the-art research, such as those covered in the SKM workshop, which was initiated with NSF support in 2004, and has been held every two years.

This project will focus on supporting extensive student attendance through travel grants at the SKM 2021 Workshop and foster their interaction with researchers and practitioners from academia, industry, and government. The supported students will attend presentations and participated in discussions related to the most recent innovations, trends, and concerns including practical challenges encountered and solutions adopted with special emphasis on AI. The value of this event will be the multi-disciplinary exchange with emphasis on topics such as machine learning, privacy, trust, risk, and social and economic aspects, and technology domains such as IoT, cloud computing and big data. Topics include (a) cybersecurity, privacy, and ethics of AI, and (b) AI tools to enhance cybersecurity, trust, and privacy. The conference includes graduate students and makes a concerted effort to reach out to students and faculty of minority institutions. The students that attend this event will get a better understanding of cutting edge topics in these STEM areas, and a clearer picture of the state-of-the-discipline.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The Secure Knowledge Management (SKM) workshop is a multi-disciplinary workshop with emphasis on topics such as machine learning, privacy, trust, risk, and social and economic aspects, and technology domains such as IoT, cloud computing and big data. This workshop will include graduate students and will make a concerted effort to reach out to students of minority institutions. Students that attend SKM will get a better understanding of cutting edge topics in the STEM areas, and a clearer picture of the state-of-the-art.

 

The SKM program was held on September 24th, 2024. Several doctoral students attended to share their research and receive feedback. The event included a keynote talk by Associate Dean at W.P. Carey School of Business, a panel discussion on ‘early career success’ that featured faculty from Arizona State University, and six research presentations by the students. The presentations were relevant to topics in Information Systems and Disaster Management.

Attending students were also able to visit cutting edge research labs, for example the Arizona State University Media and Immersive eXperience (MIX) center. Students gained hands-on experience with the latest technologies that support combination of information management and data

The objective of the SKM workshop for graduate students was to bring together early career scholars for a networking and research exchange event. The scope and focus of SKM-2024 workshop were to present and discuss recent innovations, trends, and concerns including practical challenges encountered and solution adopted with special emphasis on AI and Secure Knowledge Management.

Invited students were able to share and receive feedback on research, participate in a panel discussion on early career success, and listen to a keynote talk by the NSF program director on developing a research pipeline. Discussed research topics included information systems security, steganography, disaster management, machine learning, and natural language processing. Invited students were also able to learn from other research centers on Arizona State University’s campus. In particular they were able to learn more about data visualization.

 


Last Modified: 02/04/2025
Modified by: Raghav Rao
